text:
According to the Vostok Ice Core Records, CO2 level changes have followed Earth's overall temperature changes at an 800 year lag for the last 800,000 years.  That means that our current CO2 levels are the result of Earth's overall temperature 800 years ago.  World leaders have convinced their dependents that this works in the reverse order, relatively quickly, and that we are to blame, so that they can tax us out of a false shared guilt in order to be able to afford to "fight" climate change, an unstoppable natural cycle.  The following is the source of this information:

Historical Carbon Dioxide Record from the Vostok Ice Core

Investigators
J.-M. Barnola, D. Raynaud, C. Lorius
Laboratoire de Glaciologie et de G√©ophysique de l'Environnement,
CNRS, BP96,
38402 Saint Martin d'Heres Cedex, France

N.I. Barkov
Arctic and Antarctic Research Institute,
Beringa Street 38, 199397,
St. Petersburg, Russia

Period of Record
417,160 - 2,342 years BP

Methods
In January 1998, the collaborative ice-drilling project between Russia, the United States, and France at the Russian Vostok station in East Antarctica yielded the deepest ice core ever recovered, reaching a depth of 3,623 m (Petit et al. 1997, 1999). Ice cores are unique with their entrapped air inclusions enabling direct records of past changes in atmospheric trace-gas composition. Preliminary data indicate the Vostok ice-core record extends through four climate cycles, with ice slightly older than 400 kyr (Petit et al. 1997, 1999). Because air bubbles do not close at the surface of the ice sheet but only near the firn-ice transition (that is, at ~90 m below the surface at Vostok), the air extracted from the ice is younger than the surrounding ice (Barnola et al. 1991). Using semiempirical models of densification applied to past Vostok climate conditions, Barnola et al. (1991) reported that the age difference between air and ice may be ~6000 years during the coldest periods instead of ~4000 years, as previously assumed. Ice samples were cut with a bandsaw in a cold room (at about -15¬∞C) as close as possible to the center of the core in order to avoid surface contamination (Barnola et al. 1983). Gas extraction and measurements were performed with the "Grenoble analytical setup," which involved crushing the ice sample (~40 g) under vacuum in a stainless-steel container without melting it, expanding the gas released during the crushing in a pre-evacuated sampling loop, and analyzing the CO2 concentrations by gas chromatography (Barnola et al. 1983). The analytical system, except for the stainless-steel container in which the ice was crushed, was calibrated for each ice sample measurement with a standard mixture of CO2 in nitrogen and oxygen. For further details on the experimental procedures and the dating of the successive ice layers at Vostok, see Barnola et al. (1987, 1991), Lorius et al. (1985), and Petit et al. (1999).

Trends
There is a close correlation between Antarctic temperature and atmospheric concentrations of CO2 (Barnola et al. 1987). The extension of the Vostok CO2 record shows that the main trends of CO2 are similar for each glacial cycle. Major transitions from the lowest to the highest values are associated with glacial-interglacial transitions. During these transitions, the atmospheric concentrations of CO2 rises from 180 to 280-300 ppmv (Petit et al. 1999). The extension of the Vostok CO2 record shows the present-day levels of CO2 are unprecedented during the past 420 kyr. Pre-industrial Holocene levels (~280 ppmv) are found during all interglacials, with the highest values (~300 ppmv) found approximately 323 kyr BP. When the Vostok ice core data were compared with other ice core data (Delmas et al. 1980; Neftel et al. 1982) for the past 30,000 - 40,000 years, good agreement was found between the records: all show low CO2 values [~200 parts per million by volume (ppmv)] during the Last Glacial Maximum and increased atmospheric CO2 concentrations associated with the glacial-Holocene transition. According to Barnola et al. (1991) and Petit et al. (1999) these measurements indicate that, at the beginning of the deglaciations, the CO2 increase either was in phase or lagged by less than ~1000 years with respect to the Antarctic temperature, whereas it clearly lagged behind the temperature at the onset of the glaciations.

References
Barnola, J.-M., D. Raynaud, A. Neftel, and H. Oeschger. 1983. Comparison of CO2 measurements by two laboratories on air from bubbles in polar ice. Nature 303:410-13.

Barnola, J.-M., D. Raynaud, Y.S. Korotkevich, and C. Lorius. 1987. Vostok ice core provides 160,000-year record of atmospheric CO2. Nature 329:408-14.

Barnola, J.-M., P. Pimienta, D. Raynaud, and Y.S. Korotkevich. 1991. CO2-climate relationship as deduced from the Vostok ice core: A re-examination based on new measurements and on a re-evaluation of the air dating. Tellus 43(B):83- 90.

Delmas, R.J., J.-M. Ascencio, and M. Legrand. 1980. Polar ice evidence that atmospheric CO2 20,000 yr BP was 50% of present. Nature 284:155-57.

Jouzel, J., C. Lorius, J.R. Petit, C. Genthon, N.I. Barkov, V.M. Kotlyakov, and V.M. Petrov. 1987. Vostok ice core: A continuous isotopic temperature record over the last climatic cycle (160,000 years). Nature 329:403-8.

Lorius, C., J. Jouzel, C. Ritz, L. Merlivat, N.I. Barkov, Y.S. Korotkevich, and V.M. Kotlyakov. 1985. A 150,000-year climatic record from Antarctic ice. Nature 316:591-96.

Neftel, A., H. Oeschger, J. Schwander, B. Stauffer, and R. Zumbrunn. 1982. Ice core measurements give atmospheric CO2 content during the past 40,000 yr. Nature 295:220-23.

Pepin, L., D. Raynaud, J.-M. Barnola, and M.F. Loutre. 2001. Hemispheric roles of climate forcings during glacial-interglacial transitions as deduced from the Vostok record and LLN-2D model experiments. Journal of Geophysical Research 106 (D23): 31,885-31,892.

Petit, J.R., I. Basile, A. Leruyuet, D. Raynaud, C. Lorius, J. Jouzel, M. Stievenard, V.Y. Lipenkov, N.I. Barkov, B.B. Kudryashov, M. Davis, E. Saltzman, and V. Kotlyakov. 1997. Four climate cycles in Vostok ice core. Nature 387: 359-360.

Petit, J.R., J. Jouzel, D. Raynaud, N.I. Barkov, J.-M. Barnola, I. Basile, M. Benders, J. Chappellaz, M. Davis, G. Delayque, M. Delmotte, V.M. Kotlyakov, M. Legrand, V.Y. Lipenkov, C. Lorius, L. P√©pin, C. Ritz, E. Saltzman, and M. Stievenard. 1999. Climate and atmospheric history of the past 420,000 years from the Vostok ice core, Antarctica. Nature 399: 429-436.

Raynaud, D., and J.-M. Barnola. 1985. An Antarctic ice core reveals atmospheric CO2 variations over the past few centuries. Nature 315:309-11.

CITE AS: Barnola, J.-M., D. Raynaud, C. Lorius, and N.I. Barkov. 2003. Historical CO2 record from the Vostok ice core. In Trends: A Compendium of Data on Global Change. Carbon Dioxide Information Analysis Center, Oak Ridge National Laboratory, U.S. Department of Energy, Oak Ridge, Tenn., U.S.A.

text: I am a climate change denier. Not because I think we as a human race are incapable of affecting our global climate, (consider the CFCs and the hole in the O-zone layer), but because the data on global climate change does not convince me. It's as simple as that. For instance, in 2006, it was "global warming," now it's been revised to "global climate change" with an emphasis on increased natural disasters. Is global climate change really the cause? or could it simply be that we have greater populations in more areas around the globe, with more sophisticated equipment to measure our weather? and maybe it just so happened that the Earth had a tumultuous few years in the 00's as part of it's natural cycle? I've not been able to find any reliable information to dispute this hypothesis, and I know I'm not the only one whose asked. If the data were convincing, I would be more than happy to support agendas to help restore the Earth's natural climate cycle, but as it stands, there are still too many unanswered questions, and not enough data in my view.

text:
This x1000. I'll be the first to say that climate change presents a challenge that we can't overlook. However there are other problems we should deal with first. Why? Because it is beyond all doubt that these problems are the direct consequence of our own actions (e.g. radiation from coal-burning and toxicity in our water, soil, air and home environments); AND because they are problems we can tackle and solve with simple - if strict - legislation and regulation.

Take CFCs for example: once this problem was identified and prioritised, it was solved within a decade or so and the ozone layer is on the way to recovery. We could, and should¬†tackle the issues of sugar overconsumption and environmental toxicity of many kinds in a very similar way. All of our lives and the health of our environment as a whole would be improved, which will put everyone in a better position to support ongoing mitigation strategies to deal with our changing climate.

text:
Nothing like a one-sided discussion of climate change (shame on TED-Ed).

At this point, climate science cannot prove how the climate changes as a result of adding greenhouse gases to the atmosphere. Certainly, the concentration of these gases is increasing and sometimes temperature does as well. Of course, as in the case of the last 17+ years CO2 has been increasing and yet temperature has been flat to lower.
¬†
We can measure how much CO2 and other greenhouse gases are in the astmosphere. We can measure temperture. However, we cannot measure how much human actiivty contributes to the observed change in climate and that is the key question. Absent instruments that can provide this answer we have to rely on computer models. Unfortunately, as of now there is no model(s) that accurately simulates observed climate variations. This indicates that the basic theory incorporated in the models is inadequate and the science is definitely not settled. Without verified models it is nonsensical to use their output for policy decisions.
Some point to weather anomolies and try to argue that they are due to human activities. What do we find? Are things getting worse? Looking at 60 years of tornado data, 120 years of hurricane data or droughts over the past 1,000 years there is no evidence that it is gloom and doom time.

So, at this point we have not direct evidence or verified computer models to support the claim that human activities are a significant factor in changing climate. Nobody disagrees that human activities do contribute to some extent to climate change but there is no evidence that this is a significant effect. This is not a good basis for policy decisions.

To be sure, however, we should not stand still. Further research is needed as well as a national energy policy that will more efficiently use fossil fuels rather than the current costly brute force schemes being pushed by EPA and other Federal agencies.

text: ¬†@Pawe≈Ç Wolnicki¬† I dont see how warming produces CO2. How is CO2 a result OF global warming? it doesn't make sense. It is one cause (not the only one!) of the warming, and it's likely the largest player being that statistics have shown that the increase of CO2 and increase in global temperature (we're talking tenths of a degree average) correlate. Physics agrees as well, being that light can be absorbed by various molecules, their shape, size and density dictates what "color" they absorb, and appear to be (red paint used to use Iron for coloring). CO2 happens to love infrared, the wavelength most notably associated with direct heat. But not at the wavelengths the sun produces, those are much too small (high frequency), it's not until the earth absorbs and re-releases its own infrared energy that CO2 "shines". The earth, being much cooler, gives much longer wavelengths (lower frequency). This makes it easier for CO2 to absorb. In a nutshell, heat from the sun gets in freely, heat from the earth gets trapped. Hence the term "greenhouse effect"

text: The polar vortex is due in part to the higher global temperatures we're experiencing. During the northern hemisphere winter the Arctic gets extremely cold as the sun barely hits it, all the areas circling the Arctic do receive some sun each day though. The difference in heat (all heat ultimately was sourced from the sun) causes a pressure difference between the Arctic and the surrounding areas trapping the polar winds in a vortex. This year, because of the excess of CO2, the Arctic retained a higher amount of it's heat causing the temperature and hence pressure difference to not be as pronounced, allowing the angular momentum of the polar winds to break free from their pressure wall and reach areas with much lower latitudes than normal such as North America.

"‚ÄúOne Hundred Authors Against Einstein was (a short book) published in 1931 [which said the Theory of Relativity is wrong]. author: colion

text:
¬†@colion¬† Did you know that since 2007 when the American Association of Petroleum Geologists revised their previous statements there has not been a single nationally or internationally recognized scientific organization that disagrees with the hypothesis of anthropogenic climate change?

A review of published papers between 1991 and 2012 found that of the 13,950 articles in peer-reviewed journals on the subject of climate change, only 24 rejected anthropogenic global warming.

Several scientific organizations have explicitly used the term "consensus" in their statements: American Association for the Advancement of Science, US National Academy of Sciences, Joint Science Academies, American Meteorological Society, Network of African Science Academies, International Union for Quaternary Research and the Australian Coral Reef Society to name a few.

As you say a consensus alone does not prove that anthropogenic climate change is occurring however the weight of evidence combined with the existing consensus strongly suggests that is the case. Until someone can provide some meaningful evidence to the contrary the scientific consensus should be considered the most reliable source of information on the subject.

text:
¬†@Catherine Ditheridge¬†
As far as the societies go you are behind the times.¬† The published positions are often written by a small group without the consent of the members.¬† As a result, many distinguished scientists, including Nobel Laureates, have resigned.¬† In response, the societies are revisiting their positions.¬† The most visible is the American Physical Society with over 50,000 members who a few months ago appointed a committee consisting equally of distinguished ‚Äúwarmists‚Äù and ‚Äúskeptics‚Äù to propose an updated position.¬† The transcripts of the committee‚Äôs meetings are being distributed to the membership in order to ensure that the process is transparent and that the members have appropriate input.¬† From what I have heard I‚Äôm sure that the APS position will be restated in a balanced ‚Äúgrey‚Äù (not black and white) statement which is appropriate as the subject is ‚Äúgrey‚Äù.¬† Many believe that such a statement from one of the largest scientific organizations will open the ‚Äúflood gates‚Äù for other societies.¬† I have little doubt that this business will follow an increasingly "softened"¬†path.

The issue of published agreement that you mention has been debunked many times. ¬†You will benefit from reading such literature, including the following but many more such studies have been published:¬†
http://friendsofscience.org/assets/documents/97_Consensus_Myth.pdf

Your appeal on any level to consensus is outside of any discussion about the scientific merits of arguments on either side. ¬†Consensus, as noted by Professor Reiter, resides in the political sphere and numerous examples from Galileo to Einstein have shown that it does not trump science.¬† The weight of evidence does not support significant forcing by human activities and is an unsubstantiated and unjustified claim.¬† Adding the weight of consensus, as you do, to this weak position does not produce a convincing argument that stands up to scientific scrutiny.
author: colion

text:
It hasn't been debunked, the study you provided is hardly stellar reading material. It straight up gives wrong numbers in it's executive summary, global warming did not stop 16 years ago, this is a common twisting of figures that relies on 1998 being an incredibly hot year, if you look at the numbers from 97 or 99 the picture is very different.

Moving into the meaty bit of the study it starts with Oreskes and immediately misrepresents the figures by focusing on the 13 out of 1117 papers that explicitly endorse consensus and ignoring the 470 studies that were taken out of the final figures because they weren't about climate change. In reality 478 / 647 of the papers either confirm or work from the perspective that AGW is happening which backs up the 75% figure.

Doran and Zimmerman was rubbish, I'll give you that but that is why it is rarely cited.

I'm bored of breaking it down now so I'll just say that the paper as a whole just shows that most of the studies that took a position on AGW supported that it was happening and assumes that any paper where a percentage figure isn't given it worthless.

Also it relies heavily on the Bodenstein criticism which was wholly speculative and ran in the face of other prominent reviews of the work he was criticizing.

It's a bit of a mess really, grasping at straws at best.
author: Catherine Ditheridge

text:
¬†@Catherine Ditheridge¬† You are wrong with respect to a pause in global warming.¬†¬†¬†HadCRUT3 shows warming to 1878, cooling to 1911, warming to '41, cooling to '64, warming to 1998 and cooling to '11. Warming rate from '64-'98 was equal to that for '11-'41.¬† Since '01, satellite, balloons and ground stations all show cooling.¬† Correcting the ground stations for the urban heat effect reduces land warming by 1/2 since '80.¬† Bottom line no matter how one slices or dices it we are in a pause in temperature¬†despite the increase in CO2.¬† Even IPCC acknowledged this in IPCC¬†AR5.¬† But take heart as¬†temperature will undoubtedly creep up some more consistent with coming out of the Little Ice Age in the 1800s.¬†

As for the FoS study, if you don't like it you are free to¬†look at the¬†many others that reach the same conclusion.¬† And you might want to look at the recently published study by NIPCC which references 3,000 or so peer reviewed papers that refute the conclusions of IPCC AR5.¬† Any rational person is free to compare the these reports and reach their own conclusion.¬† In any case, this is neither here nor there as consensus means nada in the scientific world and is only feeds the emotions of¬†those who cannot get beyond "political science".

text:
Worth as a noun is a universal concept and exists with any creature that has contemplated the value of building a shelter or sleeping amongst predators.¬† Too many talk about humans not being alone on the planet - and true, we're not.¬† ..and what is the value of a world full of animals without humans?¬†

¬†Animals attack and eat each other without mercy.¬† They're not vegetarians that live in peace and harmony.¬†¬† After millions of years, they haven't progressed intellectually.¬† There's¬†no concerted effort amongst them to communicate with other species.¬† They're still barking, growling, hissing, and biting.¬†

None of them have ever gathered in social groups and pondered their own existence, developed technology, constructed cities, or created a space exploration administration.¬† They haven't made any advancements in medicine or scientific research.¬† They don't have abilities in the arts or entertainment.

They haven't flown satellites to Jupiter or Saturn and nor have they launched a successful mission that is sending a televised examination of Mars from a remote controlled science lab.¬†To the contrary, they're the quickest way to die if you walk through a jungle without a weapon.¬†

This world without humans is insignificant.¬† If there are intelligent beings beyond earth, they won't be interested in coming here just to communicate with animals.¬†
